displayed_text: Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects?

Patient: da Vinci procedure, da Vinci procedure. Doctor: Look at you. Get you on the table just like that. (laughs) Patient: da Vinci procedure (makes whistle noise) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Snip, snip, snip, bzzz. (makes various noises) Doctor: See that. You’re Patient: Been there, done that. Doctor: I know… Patient: Been there done that, so it’s… Doctor: We might come around to that. Who knows. It’s twenty-seventeen right? Patient: That’s… That’s right. Doctor: It would be nice to get. The other, the other part…

Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But once we found out, she will be in touch. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: To let you know what we’re going to do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um. Doctor: Did, uh, did she get tested for it? Family Member: She did not get tested, but Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But, uh, E_’s gonna want to know. Patient: My daughter who just had this, our third grandson, would, I’m sure would want to know. Family Member: I’m sure for E_. Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know.

Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones. Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial.

Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles. Doctor: So, right. So, we start the hormones. We get you chemotherapy. We give you a little bit of a break. I don’t know if it’s a month- Healthcare Professional: Mm Hmm. Doctor: And then you have your surgery. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then, based on what we see under the microscope, they can discern whether or not we’re gonna give you radiation to your prostate to try to clean up the area or is it all pretty decent. And, then they can plan the spot radiation to the sites that we’ve seen before. (pause) Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and Doctor: Right. So, they’ll be more pictures at that point. Sometimes when we use the hormones and the chemo, uh, things start to heal. Things that we can’t see now with our pictures. And, then, things pop up. Uh. And that’s just because they’re healing, so we can now see them. Uh. But your PSA is zero and you feel well with taking your prostate out, so that would then give them information as to sort of, okay this is what we can offer at that point. Patient: Okay. What’s the downside? Doctor: Umm. Downside? More therapy than you should be getting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: A lot of therapy in a young guy. So, we think you’re the right guy to get it because you can probably handle it all. Uh, but T_ and I, when we’ve been working together this last week, uh - There’s a lot of safety built in that, you know, instead of going six cycles, we could stop after four cycles. You know, some of these sorts of just tweaking things to make sure we don’t, uh, you know, go too far. And, that’s some of the reason why we see you every three weeks when you’re on the chemo. Uh. ‘Cuz we wanna make sure we’re not going too far. Uh. And, you know, the whole concept of doing this together, there is nothing about this that we haven’t done before, but it’s not around the country. And, the big question is, “Is this much therapy appropriate?” (pause) Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy?

Patient: … I’ve been playing dodgeball and I come up with something and then I just. Doctor: Find an excuse. Patient: Yeah you know it. Doctor: We got to fix that. Patient: Yeah. I know. I know you’re gonna take care of me. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll get my paperwork here. I’ll have you see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and… (pause) Patient: So how have you been doing sir? Doctor: I’m doing fine. Patient: Did you, did you - Were you able to recoup? Doctor: Well I’m still trying. Patient: You’re still trying (laughs) Doctor: That’s probably the biggest drawback is the weather, cold weather.

Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: It looks, I know it’s got a little scab to it. Patient: Well, that’s because I take my fingernail and I scratch it. And the only reason I scratch it is because when your shirt hits it, it hurts. You told me to mention everything. Are these cameras on? Doctor: They are. Patient: With me, me running off at the jaws. Doctor: Today, your white count is fine. Your anemia is unchanged. So that’s normal when you’re on these medicines a lower testosterone. Your platelets are also normal. Kidney function looks good. Your albumin is better. Your alkaline phosphatase is the same. Everything else is normal.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: For a while actually that was explored as a treatment against prostate cancer – Family Member: Oh. Doctor: - to give mega doses and I mean grams and grams of calcium. Patient: Didn’t work. Doctor: No it was worse. Laughs]] Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Not only did it not work, but pause]] Mm, hmm? Patient: So, then we’ll go up front and get the appointment. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we leave. Doctor: So about well six weeks would be about June eighteen, so sometime that week I need a PSA.

Patient: I got that did. Doctor: Yep. See slowly we’re fixing you up. Patient: Yeah I’ll be good in no time. Okay. (laughs) Doctor: The only thing not behaving is your prostate number though. Patient: That’s because I didn’t get it. After three months it was four and a half. That’s what happened. Doctor: Yeah. You still shouldn’t be sort of rising. Patient: I shouldn’t go… Doctor: So I think what we’re gonna do because it’s been a while since we checked your bone scan and your CAT scan. Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: Because remember we had those lymph nodes, we tried to get at those lymph nodes and this way we just want to recheck again because your last set of scans was twenty sixteen. So it’s probably a good idea to look Patient: Hmm yeah. Doctor: So W____’s gonna write out the paperwork for the bone scan.

Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term. Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay?

Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there. Doctor: Okay, that's fine. Let me print this out for you so that you can see what I'm talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll print both of them. Because the way that we, oh no there’s a lot of stuff coming out. So let me first sort of describe what we call like the stages of prostate cancer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: I’ll use the back of this. I think we talked about this last time, but I'll just, if I'm repeating myself and you get it, just say I remember all of this. So stages, so first you have what we call localized. Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But uh we’ll see how it goes. Family Member: Alright. I know in the beginning it will be more - Doctor: Next week though I was going to say just so we have enough time to get the results back, we should plan for like Thursday or Friday so we give it enough time because you know my worry is if I have you come in next Tuesday I may not have the results back from today’s blood work. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: So back here next Thursday or Friday? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah I was thinking Friday might be a little bit safer just to be on the safe side. Next Friday. Family Member: Okay. So just the one day? Patient: A week from Friday. Doctor: Yeah, yeah just for the one time. And that time you’re not getting any treatment it will be just to make decisions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The other way we could do it is we could do two weeks from today, but uh then the end of treatment stuff that S needs to do for this particular study since we’re stopping this study, that needs to happen within ten days from now.

Patient: No. My mom she’s… Doctor: Okay, somebody’s there right? Patient: Yes she – I just got to call – she out shopping right now. Doctor: Okay, no because I was gonna give you some Benadryl here also for your congestion. Sometimes um the… Patient: What’s it - For the sinus? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: Yeah… Doctor: And it can help with any reactions that uh from the chemo too. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So okay. (whispering inaudibly to herself) Patient: No. Doctor: I’ll send it right here? Patient: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled
Which of the following best describe you.Other: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Other

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play. Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation.
